Sudah Tahu Ada Gerbang Neraka di Museum Jepang?
05 Nov 2019, 21:16 by Putu Intan Raka Cinti


Gerbang Neraka di Museum Jepang. (Foto: By Roman Suzuki, CC BY 3.0)

Ueno - The Gates of Hell atau Gerbang Neraka menjadi salah satu koleksi terkenal di The National Museum of Western Art, Jepang. Penasaran dengan kisah di balik namanya yang bikin ngeri?The National Museum of Western Art yang terletak di Ueno ini merupakan museum yang memamerkan berbagai koleksi terutama yang berasal dari Eropa, termasuk di dalamnya adalah karya-karya seniman kondang Prancis, Auguste Rodin.Salah satu karya Rodin yang terkenal di sini adalah The Gates of Hell atau Gerbang Neraka. Seperti namanya, patung ini berbentuk gerbang tiga dimensi dengan tinggi 6 meter, panjang 4 meter, dan lebar 1 meter. Gerbang yang dilapisi perunggu ini menyimpan kisah yang dituangkan dalam bentuk relief.Dilansir dari situs resmi museum, Rodin mulanya membuat gerbang ini sebagai pintu masuk Museum of Decorative Arts di Paris pada 1880. Dalam pembuatannya, ia terinspirasi sastra klasik berjudul Divine Comedy karangan sastrawan Italia, Dante Alighieri. Ia mengambil bagian pertama dari Divine Comedy yaitu Inferno, atau berarti neraka dalam bahasa Italia, untuk diadopsi dalam bentuk patung gerbang.Meskipun terinspirasi dari Inferno, Rodin juga mengembangkan karyanya berdasarkan imajinasi sendiri. Untuk inspirasi artistik, ia berpatokan pada patung Michelangelo dan Gerbang Surga Ghiberti di Florence.


Gerbang Surga Lorenzo Ghiberti di Florence. (Foto:

Pada gerbang itu terdapat lebih dari 180 tokoh yang tampak berjuang untuk membebaskan diri dari Gerbang Neraka. Mereka digambarkan sebagai tokoh yang ingin keluar dari kesedihan dan keinginan yang tak terpenuhi.Association for Public Art menjelaskan beberapa makna dari relief yang ada pada Gerbang Neraka.Patung 'Three Shades' yang terletak di bagian paling atas gerbang ini terinspirasi dari karya Dante. 'Three Shades' menggambarkan arwah dari orang mati yang berdiri di atas gerbang dan menunjuk tokoh-tokoh yang menderita di bawahnya.Tepat di bawah mereka ada patung 'The Thinker' yang memiliki berbagai interpretasi, mulai dari Dante yang sedang melihat tokoh-tokoh Inferno, Rodin yang memikirkan patung buatannya, sampai Adam yang tengah berkontemplasi melihat kekacauan yang ia buat usai makan buah terlarang.Kemudian bergerak ke bawah, di pintu sebelah kiri adalah gambaran Ugolino dan putra-putranya yang menderita kelaparan sampai anak-anak itu meninggal.


Gerbang Neraka di Museum Jepang. (Foto:

Lalu tepat di bawahnya adalah pasangan kekasih Paolo dan Francesca yang merupakan tokoh dalam karya Dante. Paolo berusaha meraih Francesca yang terpeleset.Sementara itu di kusen pintu kanan, di bagian paling bawah ada seorang lelaki berjanggut yang tengah berlutut, dianggap mewakili Rodin sendiri. Dan pada bagian bawah gerbang itu ada makam-makam yang mengingatkan bahwa pintu itu adalah pintu masuk ke neraka.Gerbang buatan Rodin ini mulanya tidak dilapisi perunggu. Gerbang ini baru dipamerkan dengan perunggu sekitar 1920-an. Selain dipamerkan di The National Museum of Arts, Jepang, Gerbang Neraka juga dipamerkan di 6 tempat lainnya contohnya Rodin Museum, Filadelfia dan Musee Rodin, Paris.Halaman1 Tampilkan Semua Artikel Selanjutnya Tempat Liburan Susi di Jepang: Nongkrong di Depan Kapal Pesiar(krs/msl)

Already Know There Is a Hell's Gate in the Japanese Museum?
05 Nov 2019, 21:16 by Putu Intan Raka Cinti


Hell's Gate in the Japanese Museum. (Photo: By Roman Suzuki, CC BY 3.0)

Ueno - The Gates of Hell is one of the famous collections at The National Museum of Western Art, Japan. Intrigued by the story behind his name that horrifies? The National Museum of Western Art, located in Ueno, is a museum that exhibits various collections, especially those from Europe, including works by famous French artist, Auguste Rodin. One of the works The famous Rodin here is The Gates of Hell. As the name suggests, this statue is a three-dimensional gate with a height of 6 meters, a length of 4 meters, and a width of 1 meter. This bronze-coated gate holds a story that is poured in relief. Reported from the official site of the museum, Rodin initially made this gate as the entrance to the Museum of Decorative Arts in Paris in 1880. In its manufacture, he was inspired by the classic literature entitled Divine Comedy by Italian literary writers, Dante Alighieri. He took the first part of the Divine Comedy, Inferno, or means hell in Italian, to be adopted in the form of a gate statue. Although inspired by Inferno, Rodin also developed his work based on his own imagination. For artistic inspiration, he relied on the Michelangelo statue and the Ghiberti Heaven Gate in Florence.


Gates of Heaven Lorenzo Ghiberti in Florence. (Photo:

At the gate there are more than 180 figures who appear to struggle to free themselves from the Gates of Hell. They are portrayed as figures who want to get out of sadness and unfulfilled desires. Associated for Public Art explains some of the meaning of relief in the Hell Gate. The 'Three Shades' statue located at the very top of this gate was inspired by Dante's work. 'Three Shades' depicts the spirits of the dead who stand at the top of the gate and designate figures who suffer under them. Right below them there is a statue of 'The Thinker' which has various interpretations, starting from Dante who is looking at Inferno figures, Rodin was thinking about the statue he made, until Adam who was contemplating saw the chaos he made after eating the forbidden fruit. Then moving down, at the door to the left was a picture of Ugolino and his sons suffering from starvation until the children died.


Hell's Gate in the Japanese Museum. (Photo:

Then right below him are Paolo and Francesca's lovers who are the characters in Dante's work. Paolo tried to grab Francesca who slipped. Meanwhile on the right door frame, at the very bottom was a bearded man who was kneeling, considered to represent Rodin himself. And at the bottom of the gate there are tombs that remind that the door is the entrance to hell. Rodin's gate was originally not coated with bronze. This new gate was exhibited with bronze around the 1920s. Besides being exhibited at The National Museum of Arts, Japan, Hell's Gate is also exhibited in 6 other places for example Rodin Museum, Philadelphia and Musee Rodin, Paris.Page1 Show All Next Articles Susi Vacation Rentals in Japan: Hang out in Front of Yacht (krs / msl )
